titleInfo.title: James M. Buchanan on Keynesian economics

location.physicalLocation: Special Collections, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

mods.abstract: Article from Sidelines, student publication of Middle Tennessee State University. Describes a talk given by James M. Buchanan on campus on Feb. 7, 1977. His talk covered the impacts of Keynesian economic policy in the wake of the depression of the 1930s and the prospects for a constitutional amendment to address deficits of the U.S. government. A photograph of the speaker is included.
mods.accessCondition: Copyright held by Middle Tennessee State University; May be reproduced for educational and research purposes. Credit image to Special Collections, James E. Walker Library, MTSU

relatedItem.abstract: This collection documents the family of James McGill Buchanan (1919-2013), MTSU alumnus and 1986 winner of the Nobel Prize for Economics. His family has deep roots in middle Tennessee, including an 18th-century settler of Nashville and 19th-century Governor. Mr. Buchanan earned his B.S. at Middle Tennessee State Teachers College in 1940, followed by his M.A. in Economics at UT-Knoxville and his Ph.D. at the University of Chicago.

mods.note: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
